issue.title: Validating nested dataclasses without class ownership

repository.name: pydantic
repository.description: Data validation using Python type hints

issue.body:
# Question

Hi! I want to validate a model whose definition I don't control from a package we depend on. That model consists of nested dataclasses. I thought I'd be able to subclass that model with pydantic's `dataclass` decorator and it would work just fine, and it does, but only if the model I am subclassing doesn't have any nested dataclasses. Here's what I mean:

```py
from dataclasses import dataclass
from pydantic.dataclasses import dataclass as pydataclass

# FROM AN EXTERNAL PACKAGE
@dataclass
class NavbarButton:
    href: str


@dataclass
class Navbar:
    button: NavbarButton
# END EXTERNAL PACKAGE

@pydataclass
class CustomNavbar(Navbar):
    pass

navbar = CustomNavbar("https://example.com",)
print(navbar)
```

This throws:

`RuntimeError: no validator found for <class '__main__.NavbarButton'>, see arbitrary_types_allowed in Config`

Is there any way to get Pydantic to play nice with these classes except by essentially copying code?

body:
Hi,
I modified pydantic `dataclass` decorator to support builtin dataclasses and add validation.
I would like some feedback on [this feature](https://github.com/samuelcolvin/pydantic/pull/1817/files#diff-f6a3306d2b8af9561be776c047b45436R687): the nested dataclasses are all validated by pydantic.
I thought it would make more sense as the dataclasses can come from external packages but I was trying to see if there was some weird cases where it would be unexpected (in which case we could add something in the Config or directly in the decorator like `recursive = False`)

### Checks

* [x] I added a descriptive title to this issue
* [x] I have searched (google, github) for similar issues and couldn't find anything
* [x] I have read and followed [the docs](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/) and still think this is a bug

<!-- Sorry to sound so draconian, but every second saved replying to issues is time spend improving pydantic :-) -->

# Bug

Output of `python -c "import pydantic.utils; print(pydantic.utils.version_info())"`:
```
             pydantic version: 1.7
            pydantic compiled: True
                 install path: /Users/kittipat/pydantic_test/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pydantic
               python version: 3.7.9 (default, Sep 30 2020, 11:16:22)  [Clang 11.0.0 (clang-1100.0.33.17)]
                     platform: Darwin-19.6.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
     optional deps. installed: []
```
<!-- or if you're using pydantic prior to v1.3, manually include: OS, python version and pydantic version -->

<!-- Please read the [docs](https://pydantic-docs.helpmanual.io/) and search through issues to
confirm your bug hasn't already been reported. -->

<!-- Where possible please include a self-contained code snippet describing your bug: -->

Prior to version 1.7, it was possible to subclass from stdlib dataclass. In version 1.7, doing so will result in error. Here is a minimal repro.

```py
#!/usr/bin/env python3

from dataclasses import field, dataclass as vanilla_dataclass
from pydantic.dataclasses import dataclass

@vanilla_dataclass
class X:
    y: int = 0


@dataclass
class A(X):
    x: int = 1

@dataclass
class B:
    a: A = field(default_factory=lambda: A(x=2, y=3))


def main():
    print(B(**{"a": {"x": "4", "y": "5"}}))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

Running with version 1.6
```
B(a=A(y=5, x=4))
```

Running with version 1.7
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "dataclass.py", line 15, in <module>
    @dataclass
  File "pydantic/dataclasses.py", line 214, in pydantic.dataclasses.dataclass
    # name and type are filled in after the fact, not in __init__.
  File "pydantic/dataclasses.py", line 209, in pydantic.dataclasses.dataclass.wrap

  File "pydantic/dataclasses.py", line 138, in pydantic.dataclasses._process_class
    # +-------+-------+-------+--------+--------+
  File "dataclass.py", line 17, in <lambda>
    a: A = field(default_factory=lambda: A(x=2, y=3))
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'x'
```
